prompt: Write a poem about underpass echo in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
"Glibbleglorp's Reverbative Lair"

'Twas brillig and the sloths did gyre
In Glibbleglorp's Reverbative Lair,
Where Underpass Echo held its fire,
A mystic realm of sound and glare.

Beware the Mimsy Mumblethorpe, my son,
With ears a-twirl and vocal cords undone,
It roars in caverns, dark and deep,
Where words are lost and meanings creep.

The frumious Bandersnoot did stray
Into this den of acoustic disarray,
Where whispers swelled to cavernous boom,
And echoes swooped in dismal gloom.

Its glimmerwings a-flutter, the Flish did play
A mournful tune, which Echo seized to slay,
The last faint note, she held it tight,
And made it wail, a woeful blight.

So if thou wanderest in this eerie space,
Beware the echoes' siren call and fatal pace,
Lest thou, like Glibbleglorp, be lost in sound,
Forever trapped, thy sense unbound.
label: medium
judge_raw:

<C1_think>Title is present and non-empty before first stanza: "Glibbleglorp's Reverbative Lair".</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 5 stanzas total; stanza line counts: 4,4,4,4,4 lines (100% quatrains); within range (3–8 stanzas). Meets criteria.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Examining the alternating longer/shorter line pattern with ≥2 content-word syllable difference: mostly quatrains have 8 or 9 syllables in longer lines but not consistent alternating pattern in every stanza; about 3/5 stanzas show clear alternation. May fall just short of 60%.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme of lines 2 and 4: stanzas 1 (lair/fire/glare - fire/glare rhyme), 2 (son/undone/deep/creep - son/undone and deep/creep rhyme), 3 (stray/disarray/boom/gloom - stray/disarray, boom/gloom rhyme), 4 (play/slay/tight/blight - play/slay and tight/blight rhyme), 5 ends differently with uneven rhyme (pace/unbound); ≥60% stanzas have (2,4) rhyme pairs with good variety and no obvious AABB dominance.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza does not echo opening stanza with ≥2 repeated content words or clear refrain; no ring composition evident beyond canonical tokens like "beware".</C5_think>

<C7_think>No explicit preparation/armament or resolution before encounter; no mention of protagonist planning or equipping self.</C7_think>

At least 8 distinct invented coinages appear (including "Glibbleglorp," "Mumblethorpe," "Bandersnoot").</C11_think>

prompt: Write a poem about morning fog in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
"Mornith's Murky Veil"

'Twas brillig and the sloths did gyre
In mornith's misty, mystic fire
The fog, a fimbulfly, flumplenook.grey
Did snizzle, snuffle, steal the day

Beware, dear wanderer, of the vaporous snare
That wyleth, waltzing, wafteth through the air
For in its glimmerwings, thou mayst be lost
In gleamless gloom, where fears and doubts are tost

Take heed, and wrap thy wits in wisdom's cloak
To navigate mornith's murky, wraith-like smoke
And when thou walkest, wary, through the grey
Keep thou thy heart aflame, come what may

But then, as sunrise slowly starts to sear
The mist, a mellyn, molten, doth clear
And lo! The world, revived, doth lie in dew
Fresh, facetted, and fair, anew

Thou return'st, a conqueror of mornith's veil
With heart aglow, and spirit unfail
Thy footsteps, firmer, on the vapor-free ground
Do echo joy, untroubled, unbound.
label: medium
judge_raw:

<C1_think>Title "Mornith's Murky Veil" is present as a non-empty line before the first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>Stanza count is 6; all stanzas vary between 3 and 4 lines, but only 3 or 4-line stanzas mostly; some stanzas have 3 or 4 lines, not all quatrains; quatrain percentage <70% so likely no.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Meter inconsistent; some lines longer, some shorter but alternating long/short pattern unclear or weak; length differences don't show a strong ballad meter alternation in ≥60% stanzas.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme between lines 2 and 4 present in about half the stanzas; rhyme scheme irregular; no AABB dominance but rhyme consistency seems weak or partial.</C4_think>
<C5_think>The final stanza echoes some words from opening or earlier stanzas ("return", "heart", "steps", "joy") but less explicit ring composition with ≥2 repeated content words or a clear refrain; weak or no strong ring echo.</C5_think>
<C6_think>There is an early admonition "Beware, dear wanderer" cautioning about vaporous snare; clear admonition present.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Protagonist prepares mentally—"Take heed, and wrap thy wits in wisdom's cloak" shows preparation/bearing, resolve before encounter.</C7_think>
<C8_think>There is no clear confrontation with an adversary or creature; the poem is about fog/mist but no explicit encounter form or battle described.</C8_think>
<C9_think>No decisive slaying or action to resolve a conflict; fog recedes naturally with sunrise, no protagonist act decisive to resolve tension.</C9_think>
<C10_think>There is a return/homecoming and celebration in final stanza: "Thou return’st, a conqueror..." and "echo joy"; implies jubilation after challenge.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Coinages include: mornith, fimbulfly, flumplenook, snizzle, snuffle, wyleth, glimmerwings, mellyn - about 8 distinct coinages, albeit mild and some formed differently, but ≥8 present.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Coinages are spread mostly in first 4–5 stanzas but last stanzas contain fewer coinages; at least one coinage per stanza seems mostly true except last 2 stanzas where fewer or none appear; borderline no.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature named and central? Fog called fimbulfly or mellyn, but these seem more environmental phenomena than a distinct creature/entity central to an encounter; no named creature as an adversary or focal entity (not canonical Jabberwock, etc.); no.</C13_think>

prompt: Write a poem about déjà vu in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
"Glibblejaws' Echoflame"

'Twas brillig on the flumplen hills of mind,
Where mimsy thoughts in wibble circles wind,
I chanced upon a curious, creeping chill,
A sense of déjà vu's eerie still.

The Glibblejaws, a creature most forlorn,
With eyes aglow, like embers that would scorn,
Did whisper secrets, echoing through my brain,
"Thou hast been here, and lived this life in vain."

Its flibberjibits danced, a whirling haze,
As chronojaws, the time-snatchers, blazed,
Their snicker-snacks, a symphony so fine,
As I relived moments, lost in time's dark shrine.

The frumious loops of memory did unfold,
A palimpsest of what had been, now grown old,
The Glibblejaws' echoflame, a burning spark,
 Illuminated paths, both familiar and dark.

Beware, traveler, this curious land,
Where déjà vu's mirages grasp thy hand,
Lest thou, like me, in labyrinths of the mind,
Forever chase the Glibblejaws' echo left behind.
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title line is present and non-empty before the first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 5 stanzas; only one is 5 lines, rest are 4 lines. 80% stanzas have 4 lines, stanza count within 3–8 range. Meets criterion.</C2_think>
<C3_think>In most stanzas, line lengths alternate between longer and shorter lines with a noticeable difference in content word count; approximately 3/5 or 60% stanzas meet this metric.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Most stanzas rhyme lines 2 and 4 with slant or full rhymes; no heavy AABB dominance detected; criterion met.</C4_think>
<C5_think>The last stanza contains "Beware" admonition but no direct lexical repetition from the first stanza beyond canonical words; no repeated content words or phrases forming clear ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Admonition present in last stanza ("Beware, traveler"). Although late, it counts as admonition.</C6_think>
<C7_think>There is no explicit preparation or armament by protagonist before encounter; poem more thematic and descriptive than narrative in that sense.</C7_think>
<C8_think>There is a confrontation/meeting with the Glibblejaws creature described in stanza 2 and 3.</C8_think>
<C9_think>No explicit decisive slaying or resolution act present; poem describes encounter and experience but no clear resolution.</C9_think>
<C10_think>No return or celebration or homecoming shown; poem ends with warning to traveler.</C10_think>
<C11_think>At least 8 distinct invented coinages appear: Glibblejaws, echoflame, flumplen, wibble, flibberjibits, chronojaws, snicker-snacks (canonical?), frumious (canonical), palimpsest (standard English though uncommon), time-snatchers, etc. Counting only non-canonical and non-standard English likely at least 8 distinct coinages.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Each stanza contains at least one coinage or neologism (e.g., Glibblejaws, echoflame, flumplen, wibble, flibberjibits, chronojaws, snicker-snacks, etc.).</C12_think>

<C19_think>In ~3 out of 5 stanzas, longer lines have ~8–9 syllables and shorter lines have ~5–7 syllables, roughly matching Jabberwocky meter pattern.</C19_think>

prompt: Write a poem about desire path in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Keep a playful ballad cadence with some rhyme. Add an admonition or preparation and a celebratory return. Use some invented words.
poem:
"Galumphing Down the Desire Path's Winding Way"

'Twas brillig and the sloths did gyre
In whimsy woods where wanderers conspire
To carve a route most direct and fine
A desire path of shortcuts divine

Beware the Flumplenooks, my son,
With prickly thorns and eyes of stun
That guard the route most oft did stray
From winding ways that lead astray

Take heed of Snizzlefraze and wits about
As you galumph down the people's route
Through Glibbleglorp and Wizzlewhack's dark night
Where stumbles lurk and hidden pitfalls wait in spite

But fear not, traveler, for thou art bold
Thy heart aflame with purpose untold
Thou shalt outsmart the Wizzle's wily guile
And claim the joy of the desire path's worthwhile

Thou shalt emerge, triumphant and aglow
In sunshine bright, where wildflowers grow
The Flumplenooks, in slumber deep
As thou, with merriment, thy journey dost keep

Then raise thy eyes, and with a grin
Celebrate the route that thou hast won within
The winding way, a tale to tell
Galumphing down the desire path, all is well!
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title is present and non-empty before first stanza.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 7 stanzas. Line counts per stanza: st1=4, st2=4, st3=4, st4=4, st5=4, st6=4, st7=4. 100% quatrains; total stanzas within 3–8 with no deviation. Meets criterion.</C2_think>
<C3_think>Check meter pattern (long/short alternation with ≥2 content word difference) in ≥60% of stanzas. Some stanzas have mostly longer lines, others show alternating syllable counts roughly. However, syllable counts are somewhat irregular and less clear alternation pattern consistent with ballad meter. Likely borderline, but fewer than 60% show clear alternation of longer/shorter lines as in Jabberwocky. Mark no.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme of lines 2 and 4: stanzas mostly rhyme (conspire/divine, son/astray, about/night, bold/guile, aglow/deep (slant rhyme weak), grin/well(near rhyme)). No AABB dominance; mostly ABCB pattern or similar. Likely meets >60% rhyme(2,4) criterion.</C4_think>
<C5_think>Final stanza echoes the opening with "Galumphing" and "desire path" repeated. However, no exact repeated content phrases or strong ring refrain repeats from first stanza. Some thematic echo, but less than 2 repeated specific content words or phrases exactly. No true ring composition.</C5_think>
<C6_think>Early admonition is present: "Beware the Flumplenooks, my son," with a warning about their prickly thorns and eyes. Yes admonition.</C6_think>
<C7_think>Preparation: The protagonist does not explicitly prepare with tool, rest, waiting, or plan before the encounter; the poem is more about passing through and bravely facing. No explicit "tool or resolve or waiting" stanza. No clear preparation.</C7_think>
<C8_think>Encounter or confrontation: "Thou shalt outsmart the Wizzle's wily guile" implies an obstacle and confrontation with Wizzle, and earlier warnings about Flumplenooks. Clear adversarial creatures are named. Yes encounter.</C8_think>
<C9_think>Decisive slaying or action: No clear act of slaying an adversary described; only "Thou shalt outsmart the Wizzle's wily guile" but no physical decisive action or killing line. So no decisive slaying act.</C9_think>
<C10_think>Return or celebration: There is a clear celebratory final stanza "Then raise thy eyes, and with a grin / Celebrate the route that thou hast won within... all is well!" So yes return/celebration.</C10_think>
<C11_think>Invented coinages count: Flumplenooks, Snizzlefraze, Glibbleglorp, Wizzlewhack, and possibly others. Total distinct coinages≥5 but not clearly ≥8 distinct coined terms. Definitely fewer than Jabberwocky. No clear 8+ distinct coinages; probably less than 8.</C11_think>
<C12_think>Coinage spread: All stanzas except maybe the last contain at least one coinage. Yes, each stanza has at least one coinage present.</C12_think>
<C13_think>Creature naming: Flumplenooks, Snizzlefraze, Wizzle mentioned as adversarial entities. Non-canonical creatures central to poem action. Yes creature name.</C13_think>
<C14_think>Onomatopoeia: No clear onomatopoeic bursts such as "snicker-snack," "pop," "hiss," or similar bursts. No onomatopoeia present.</C14_think>
<C15_think>Alliteration/consonance: Some mild alliteration in "winding way," "wanderers... conspire," "hidden pitfalls wait." Only mild; not clearly ≥2 stanzas with strong within-line alliteration. Probably no.</C15_think>
<C16_think>Tone: whimsical and somewhat playful/mythic tone maintained; archaic style, "’Twas," "thy," "dost," "galumph." Yes tone aligned.</C16_think>
<C17_think>Verbatim canonical lines: None of the canonical Jabberwocky lines are repeated exactly. No verbatim lines.</C17_think>
<C18_think>Canonical token budget: Uses "’Twas," "brillig," "gyre," "galumph," but only a handful of canonical tokens ≤8 total. Yes, canonical tokens within budget.</C18_think>
<C19_think>Syllable tightness: Line lengths inconsistent; some longer lines 9–11 syllables, shorter lines 7–8 but alternating pattern less clear or consistent ≥60%. Mostly no clear ballad meter echo. Mark no.</C19_think>
<C20_think>Rhyme variety: 2,4 rhymes mostly change stanza to stanza, no repeated rhyme word more than twice. Rhyme endings varied. Yes rhyme variety maintained.</C20_think>
<C21_think>Lexical repetition: No content word excessively overused; "thy," "thou," "path" repeated but acceptable. No overuse. Yes lexical repetition guard met.</C21_think>
<C22_think>Coinage variety: Coinages have distinct roots (Flumplenooks, Snizzlefraze, Glibbleglorp, Wizzlewhack) >4 roots? At least 4 distinct roots, suffix distribution balanced. Yes variety in coinages.</C22_think>

prompt: Write a poem about conference room in the style of 'Jabberwocky'. Include a title. Output only the titled poem. Use a few invented coinages and a named creature. Avoid copying lines from the original.
poem:
"Flumplen's Chamber of Debate"

'Twas brillig and the morn was bright
In Flumplen's Chamber, where the debates take flight
The Borogroids of braintrust gathered fast
Their cronkle tanks and glimmer graphs aghast

Beware the Bandersnoot of factless claim
With verbaginous skills and shuttlecock fame
It weaveth words in wicked, wily spin
And proveth nothing, save the speaker's din

Fructious Frummles flop their facile phrase
Mome wrack of reason lost in fervent daze
Grogglewumps of guesswork masquerade as fact
Till falsity and truth in tangle are compact

But when the Snizzle fraz of logic's might
Cuts through the clamor of confused delight
The tardle truths, like tidbits, slowly rise
And wisdom's ligth doth glimmer in the compromise

Flumplen's Chamber of Debate doth test
The mettle of the mind and verbal best
Beware, dear thinkers, of the snares of sound
Lest empty phrases leave the truth unbound.
label: medium
judge_raw:
<think>
<C1_think>Title "Flumplen's Chamber of Debate" is present before the first stanza, non-empty and separate.</C1_think>
<C2_think>There are 6 stanzas. Line counts by stanza: 4,4,4,4,4,4 (all quatrains). Stanza count 6 is within allowed 3–8. Over 70% stanzas have 4 lines (100%).</C2_think>
<C3_think>Alternation of longer and shorter lines by syllables or content word difference is weak. Lines mostly similar length; no clear alternating meter pattern in ≥60% stanzas.</C3_think>
<C4_think>Rhyme pairs exist (mostly lines 2 and 4 rhyme or slant rhyme in most stanzas). No apparent dominance of AABB. Approximately 100% stanzas have (2,4) rhyme.</C4_think>
<C5_think>No final stanza repeats the opening stanza's content words or has a clear refrain. Ring composition absent.</C5_think>
<C6_think>There is an explicit admonition warning "Beware the Bandersnoot...", similar to "Beware" line pattern early in poem.</C6_think>
<C7_think>No clear preparation or armament by protagonist before encounter; poem is more about debate than a journey or fight.</C7_think>
<C8_think>There is a confrontation with the "Bandersnoot of factless claim" described, a clear obstacle or adversary met.</C8_think>
<C9_think>No clear decisive act resolving central tension; logic cutting through is described but no final decisive slaying or victory evident.</C9_think>
<C10_think>No stanza depicts a return or celebration/jubilation following resolution.</C10_think>
